Then I shall perhaps make an acquaintance and that's no small victory gained over one who never addresses any but the wildest of her sex. But my chief aim is to take my gentleman off his guard, and like an invisible champion of romance examine the giant's force before I offer to combat.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: But are you sure you can act your part, and disguise your voice, so that he may mistake that, as he has already mistaken your person?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Never fear me. I think I have got the true bar cant.—Did your honour call?—Attend the Lion there.—Pipes and tobacco for the Angel.—The Lamb has been outrageous this half hour.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.l: It will do, madam. But he's here.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l:
What a bawling in every part of the house; I have scarce a moment's repose. If I go to the best
room, there I find my host and his story. If I fly to the gallery, there we have my hostess with her curtesy down to the ground. I have at last got a moment to myself, and now for recollection.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Did you call, Sir? did your honour call?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: As for Miss Hardcastle, she's too grave and sentimental for me.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Did your honour call?

div.stage: (She still places herself before him, he turning away.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: No, child (musing). Besides from the glimpse I had of her, I think she squints.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I'm sure, Sir, I heard the bell ring.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: No, No. (musing) I have pleased my father, however, by coming down, and I'll to-morrow please myself by returning.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Perhaps the other gentleman called, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I tell you, no.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I should be glad to know, Sir. We have such a parcel of servants.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: No, no, I tell you. (Looks full in her face.) Yes, child, I think I did call. I wanted—I wanted—I vow, child, you are vastly handsome.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: O la, Sir, you'll make one asham'd.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Never saw a more sprightly malicious eye. Yes, yes, my dear, I did call. Have you got any of your—a—what d'ye call it in the house?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: No, Sir, we have been out of that these ten days.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: One may call in this house, I find, to very little purpose. Suppose I should call for a taste, just by way of trial, of the nectar of your lips; perhaps I might be disappointed in that too.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Nectar! nectar! that's liquor there's no call for in these parts. French, I suppose. We keep no French wines here, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Of true English growth, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then it's odd I should not know it. We brew all sorts of wines in this house, and I have lived here these eighteen years.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Eighteen years! Why one would think, child, you kept the bar before you were born. How old are you?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: O! Sir, I must not tell my age. They say women and music should never be dated.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: To guess at this distance, you can't be much above forty (approaching.) Yet nearer I don't think so much (approaching.) By coming close to some women they look younger still; but when we come very close indeed (attempting to kiss her.)

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, keep your distance. One would think you wanted to know one's age as they do horses, by mark of mouth.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I protest, child, you use me extremely ill. If you keep me at this distance, how is it possible you and I can be ever acquainted?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: And who wants to be acquainted with you? I want no such acquaintance, not I. I'm sure you did not treat Miss Hardcastle that was here awhile ago in this obstropalous manner. I'll warrant me, before her you look'd dash'd, and kept bowing to the ground, and talk'd, for all the world, as if you was before a justice of peace.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Egad! she has hit it, sure enough. (To her.) In awe of her, child? Ha! ha! ha! A mere, aukward, squinting thing, no, no. I find you don't know me. I laugh'd, and rallied her a little; but I was unwilling to be too severe. No, I could not be too severe, curse me!

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: O! then, Sir, you are a favourite, I find, among the ladies?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Yes, my dear, a great favourite. And yet, hang me, I don't see what they find in me to follow. At the Ladies Club in town, I'm called their agreeable Rattle. Rattle, child, is not my real name, but one I'm known by. My name is Solomons. Mr. Solomons, my dear, at your service.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Hold, Sir; you were introducing me to your club, not to yourself. And you're so great a favourite there you say?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Yes, my dear. There's Mrs. Mantrap, Lady Betty Blackleg, the Countess of Sligo, Mrs. Langhorns, old Miss Biddy Buckskin, and your humble servant, keep up the spirit of the place.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then it's a very merry place, I suppose.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Yes, as merry as cards, suppers, wine, and old women can make us.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: And their agreeable Rattle, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Egad! I don't quite like this chit. She looks knowing, methinks. You laugh, child!

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I can't but laugh to think what time they all have for minding their work or their family.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: All's well, she don't laugh at me. (To her) Do you ever work, child?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ay, sure. There's not a screen or a quilt in the whole house but what can bear witness to that.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Odso! Then you must shew me your embroidery. I embroider and draw patterns myself a little. If you want a judge of your work you must apply to me.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ay, but the colours don't look well by candle light. You shall see all in the morning.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: And why not now, my angel? Such beauty fires beyond the power of resistance.—Pshaw! the father here! My old luck: I never nick'd seven that I did not throw ames ace three times following.

div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE, who stands in surprize.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: So, madam! So I find this is your modest lover. This is your humble admirer that kept his eyes fixed on the ground, and only ador'd at humble distance. Kate, Kate, art thou not asham'd to deceive your father so?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Never trust me, dear papa, but he's still the modest man I first took him for, you'll be convinced of it as well as I.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: By the hand of my body I believe his impudence is infectious! Didn't I see him seize your hand? Didn't I see him hawl you about like a milk maid? and now you talk of his respect and his modesty, forsooth!

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: But if I shortly convince you of his modesty, that he has only the faults that will pass off with time, and the virtues that will improve with age, I hope you'll forgive him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l:
The girl would actually make one run mad! I tell you I'll not be convinced. I am convinced. He has scarcely been three hours in the house, and he has already encroached on all my prerogatives. You may like his impudence, and call it modesty.
But my son-in-law, madam, must have very different qualifications.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Sir, I ask but this night to convince you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: You shall not have half the time, for I have thoughts of turning him out this very hour.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Give me that hour then, and I hope to satisfy you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Well, an hour let it be then. But I'll have no trifling with your father. All fair and open do you mind me.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, you have ever found that I considered your commands as my pride; for your kindness is such, that my duty as yet has been inclination.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: YOU surprise me! Sir Charles Marlow expected here this night? Where have you had your information?

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: You may depend upon it. I just saw his letter to Mr. Hardcastle, in which he tells him he intends setting out a few hours after his son.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Then, my Constance, all must be completed before he arrives. He knows me; and should he find me here, would discover my name, and perhaps my designs, to the rest of the family.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: The jewels, I hope, are safe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Yes, yes. I have sent them to Marlow, who keeps the keys of our baggage. In the meantime, I'll go to prepare matters for our elopement. I have had the Squire's promise of a fresh pair of horses; and, if I should not see him again, will write him further directions.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Well! success attend you. In the meantime, I'll go amuse my aunt with the old pretence of a violent passion for my cousin.

div.stage: Enter MARLOW, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I wonder what Hastings could mean by sending me so valuable a thing as a casket to keep for him, when he knows the only place I have is the seat of a post-coach at an Inn-door. Have you deposited the casket with the landlady, as I ordered you? Have you put it into her own hands?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: Yes, your honour.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: She said she'd keep it safe, did she?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: Yes, she said she'd keep it safe enough; she ask'd me how I came by it? and she said she had a great mind to make me give an account of myself.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! They're safe however. What an unaccountable set of beings have we got amongst! This little bar-maid though runs in my head most strangely, and drives out the absurdities of all the rest of the family. She's mine, she must be mine, or I'm greatly mistaken.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Bless me! I quite forgot to tell her that I intended to prepare at the bottom of the garden. Marlow here, and in spirits too!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Give me joy, George! Crown me, shadow me with laurels! Well, George, after all, we modest fellows don't want for success among the women.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Some women you mean. But what success has your honour's modesty been crowned with now, that it grows so insolent upon us?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Didn't you see the tempting, brisk, lovely, little thing that runs about the house with a bunch of keys to its girdle?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Well! and what then?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: She's mine, you rogue you. Such fire, such motion, such eyes, such lips—but, egad! she would not let me kiss them though.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: But are you so sure, so very sure of her?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Why man, she talk'd of shewing me her work above-stairs, and I am to improve the pattern.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: But how can you, Charles, go about to rob a woman of her honour?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Pshaw! pshaw! we all know the honour of the bar-maid of an inn. I don't intend to rob her, take my word for it, there's nothing in this house, I shan't honestly pay for.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: I believe the girl has virtue.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: And if she has, I should be the last man in the world that would attempt to corrupt it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: You have taken care, I hope, of the casket I sent you to lock up? It's in safety?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Yes, yes. It's safe enough. I have taken care of it. But how could you think the seat of a post-coach at an Inn-door a place of safety? Ah! numbskull! I have taken better precautions for you than you did for yourself.—I have—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I have sent it to the landlady to keep for you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: To the landlady!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: The landlady.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I did. She's to be answerable for its forth-coming, you know,

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Yes, she'll bring it forth, with a witness.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Wasn't I right? I believe you'll allow that I acted prudently upon this occasion?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: He must not see my uneasiness.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: You seem a little disconcerted though, methinks. Sure nothing has happened?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: No, nothing. Never was in better spirits in all my life. And so you left it with the landlady, who, no doubt, very readily undertook the charge?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Rather too readily. For she not only kept the casket; but, thro' her great precaution, was going to keep the messenger too. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: He! he! he! They're safe however.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: As a guinea in a miser's purse.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: So now all hopes of fortune are at an end, and we must set off without it. (To him.) Well, Charles, I'll leave you to your meditations on the pretty bar-maid, and, he! he! he! may you be as successful for yourself as you have been for me.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Thank ye, George! I ask no more. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I no longer know my own house. It's turned all topsey-turvey. His servants have got drunk already. I'll bear it no longer, and yet, from my respect for his father, I'll be calm. (To him.) Mr. Marlow, your servant. I'm your very humble servant.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Sir, your humble servant. (Aside.) What's to be the wonder now?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I believe, Sir, you must be sensible, Sir, that no man alive ought to be more welcome than your father's son, Sir. I hope you think so?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I do from my soul, Sir. I don't want much intreaty. I generally make my father's son welcome wherever he goes.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I believe you do, from my soul, Sir. But tho' I say nothing to your own conduct, that of your Servants is insufferable. Their manner of drinking is setting a very bad example in this house, I assure you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I protest, my very good Sir, that's no fault of mine. If they don't drink as they ought they are to blame. I ordered them not to spare the cellar. I did, I assure you. (To the side scene.) Here, let one of my servants come up. (To him.) My positive directions were, that as I did not drink myself, they should make up for my deficiencies below.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then they had your orders for what they do! I'm satisfied!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: They had, I assure. You shall hear from one of themselves.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: You, Jeremy! Come forward, sirrah! What were my orders? Were you not told to drink freely, and call for what you thought fit, for the good of the house?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I begin to lose my patience.

sp.speaker: JEREMY.
sp.l:
Please your honour, liberty and Fleet-street for ever! Tho' I'm but a servant, I'm as good as another
man. I'll drink for no man before supper, Sir, dammy! Good liquor will sit upon a good supper, but a good supper will not sit upon—hiccup—upon my conscience, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: You see, my old friend, the fellow is as drunk as he can possibly be. I don't know what you'd have more, unless you'd have the poor devil soused in a beer-barrel.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Zounds! He'll drive me distracted if I contain myself any longer. Mr. Marlow. Sir; I have submitted to your insolence for more than four hours, and I see no likelihood of its coming to an end. I'm now resolved to be master here, Sir, and I desire that you and your drunken pack may leave my house directly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Leave your house!—Sure you jest, my good friend? What, when I'm doing what I can to please you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I tell you, Sir, you don't please me; so I desire you'll leave my house.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Sure you cannot be serious? At this time o'night, and such a night. You only mean to banter me?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I tell you, Sir, I'm serious; and, now that my passions are rouzed, I say this house is mine, Sir; this house is mine, and I command you to leave it directly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l:
Ha! ha! ha! A puddle in a storm. I shan't stir a step, I assure you. (In a serious tone.) This, your house, fellow! It's my house. This is my
house. Mine, while I chuse to stay. What right have you to bid me leave this house, Sir? I never met with such impudence, curse me, never in my whole life before.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Nor I, confound me if ever I did. To come to my house, to call for what he likes, to turn me out of my own chair, to insult the family, to order his servants to get drunk, and then to tell me This house is mine, Sir. By all that's impudent it makes me laugh. Ha! ha! ha! Pray, Sir, (bantering.) as you take the house, what think you of taking the rest of the furniture? There's a pair of silver candlesticks, and there's a fire-screen, and here's a pair of brazen nosed bellows, perhaps you may take a fancy to them?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Bring me your bill, Sir, bring me your bill, and let's make no more words about it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: There are a set of prints too. What think you of the rake's progress for your own apartment?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Bring me your bill, I say; and I'll leave you and your infernal house directly.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then there's a mahogony table, that you may see your own face in.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: My bill, I say.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I had forgot the great chair, for your own particular slumbers, after a hearty meal.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Zounds! bring me my bill, I say, and let's hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Young man, young man, from your father's letter to me, I was taught to expect a well-bred modest man, as a visitor here, but now I find him no better than a coxcomb and a bully; but he will be down here presently, and shall hear more of it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: How's this! Sure I have not mistaken the house! Every thing looks like an inn. The servants cry, coming. The attendance is aukward; the bar-maid too to attend us. But she's here, and will further inform me. Whither so fast, child. A word with you.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Let it be short then. I'm in a hurry. (Aside.) (I believe he begins to find out his mistake, but its too soon quite to undeceive him.)

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Pray, child, answer me one question. What are you, and what may your business in this house be?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: A relation of the family, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: What. A poor relation?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Yes, Sir. A poor relation appointed to keep the keys, and to see that the guests want nothing in my power to give them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: That is, you act as the bar-maid of this inn.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Inn. O law—What brought that in your head. One of the best families in the county keep an inn. Ha, ha, ha, old Mr. Hardcastle's house an inn.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Mr. Hardcastle's house! Is this house Mr. Hardcastle's house, child!

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ay, sure. Whose else should it be.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: So then all's out, and I have been damnably imposed on. O, confound my stupid head, I shall be laugh'd at over the whole town. I shall be stuck up in caricatura in all the print-shops. The Dullissimo Maccaroni. To mistake this house of all others for an inn, and my father's old friend for an inn-keeper. What a swaggering puppy must he take me for. What a silly puppy do I find myself. There again, may I be hang'd, my dear, but I mistook you for the bar-maid.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Dear me! dear me! I'm sure there's nothing in my behavour to put me upon a level with one of that stamp.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Nothing, my dear, nothing. But I was in for a list of blunders, and could not help making you a subscriber. My stupidity saw every thing the wrong way. I mistook your assiduity for assurance, and your simplicity for allurement. But its over—This house I no more shew my face in.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l:
I hope, Sir, I have done nothing to disoblige you. I'm sure I should be sorry to affront any gentleman who has been so polite, and said so many
civil things to me. I'm sure I should be sorry (pretending to cry) if he left the family upon my account. I'm sure I should be sorry, people said any thing amiss, since I have no fortune but my character.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Generous man! I now begin to admire him. (to him.) But I'm sure my family is as good as miss Hardcastle's, and though I'm poor, that's no great misfortune to a contented mind, and, until this moment, I never thought that it was bad to want fortune.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: And why now, my pretty simplicity?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Because it puts me at a distance from one, that if I had a thousand pound I would give it all to.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l:
This simplicity bewitches me, so that if I stay I'm undone. I must make one bold effort, and leave her. (to her) Your partiality in my favour, my dear, touches me most sensibly, and
were I to live for myself alone, I could easily fix my choice. But I owe too much to the opinion of the world, too much to the authority of a father, so that—I can scarcely speak it—it affects me. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I never knew half his merit till now. He shall not go, if I have power or art to detain him. I'll still preserve the character in which I stoop'd to conquer, but will undeceive my papa, who, perhaps, may laugh him out of his resolution.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Ay, you may steal for yourselves the next time. I have done my duty. She has got the jewels again, that's a sure thing; but she believes it was all a mistake of the servants.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: But, my dear cousin, sure you won't forsake us in this distress. If she in the least suspects that I am going off, I shall certainly be locked up, or sent to my aunt Pedigree's, which is ten times worse.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: To be sure, aunts of all kinds are damn'd bad things. But what can I do? I have got you a pair of horses that will fly like Whistlejacket, and I'm sure you can't say but I have courted you nicely before her face. Here she comes, we must court a bit or two more, for fear she should suspect us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Well, I was greatly fluttered, to be sure. But my son tells me it was all a mistake of the servants. I shan't be easy, however, till they are fairly married, and then let her keep her own fortune. But what do I see! Fondling together, as I'm alive. I never saw Tony so sprightly before. Ah! have I caught you, my pretty doves! What, billing, exchanging stolen glances, and broken murmurs. Ah!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: As for murmurs, mother, we grumble a little now and then, to be sure. But there's no love lost between us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: A mere sprinkling, Tony, upon the flame, only to make it burn brighter.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Cousin Tony promises to give us more of his company at home. Indeed, he shan't leave us any more. It won't leave us cousin Tony, will it?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: O! it's a pretty creature. No, I'd sooner leave my horse in a pound, than leave you when you smile upon one so. Your laugh makes you so becoming.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Agreeable cousin! Who can help admiring that natural humour, that pleasant, broad, red, thoughtless, (patting his cheek) ah! it's a bold face.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Pretty innocence.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: I'm sure I always lov'd cousin Con's hazle eyes, and her pretty long fingers, that she twists this way and that, over the haspicholls, like a parcel of bobbins.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ah, he would charm the bird from the tree. I was never so happy before. My boy takes after his father, poor Mr. Lumpkin, exactly. The jewels, my dear Con, shall be your's incontinently. You shall have them. Isn't he a sweet boy, my dear? You shall be married to-morrow, and we'll put off the rest of his education, like Dr. Drowsy's sermons, to a fitter opportunity.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.l: Where's the 'Squire? I have got a letter for your worship.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Give it to my mamma. She reads all my letters first.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.l: I had orders to deliver it into your own hands.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Who does it come from?

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.l: Your worship mun ask that o' the letter itself.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: I could wish to know, tho'
sp.stage: [turning the letter, and gazing on it.]

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l:
Undone, undone. A letter to him from Hastings. I know the hand. If my aunt sees it, we are ruined for ever. I'll keep her employ'd
a little if I can. [To Mrs. Hardcastle.] But I have not told you, Madam, of my cousin's smart answer just now to Mr. Marlow. We so laugh'd—You must know, Madam—this way a little, for he must not hear us.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: A damn'd cramp piece of penmanship, as ever I saw in my life. I can read your print-hand very well. But here there are such handles, and shanks, and dashes, that one can scarce tell the head from the tail. To Anthony Lumpkin, Esquire. It's very odd, I can read the outside of my letters, where my own name is, well enough. But when I come to open it, it's all—buzz. That's hard, very hard; for the inside of the letter is always the cream of the correspondence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Very well, very well. And so my son was too hard for the philosopher.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Yes, Madam; but you must hear the rest, Madam. A little more this way, or he may hear us. You'll hear how he puzzled him again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: He seems strangely puzzled now himself, methinks.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: A damn'd up and down hand, as if it was disguised in liquor. [Reading.] Dear Sir. Ay, that's that. Then there's an M, and a T, and an S, but whether the next be an izzard or an R, confound me, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: What's that, my dear. Can I give you any assistance?

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Pray, aunt, let me read it. No body reads a cramp hand better than I. (twitching the letter from her.) Do you know who it is from?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Can't tell, except from Dick Ginger the feeder.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Ay, so it is, (pretending to read) Dear 'Squire, Hoping that you're in health, as I am at this present. The gentlemen of the Shake bag club has cut the gentlemen of goose-green quite out of feather. The odds—um—odd battle—um—long fighting—um here, here, it's all about cocks, and fighting; it's of no consequence, here, put it up, put it up,

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: But I tell you, Miss, it's of all the consequence in the world. I would not lose the rest of it for a guinea. Here, mother, do you make it out. Of no consequence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: How's this! (reads) Dear 'Squire, I'm now waiting for Miss Neville, with a post-chaise and pair, at the bottom of the garden, but I find my horses yet unable to perform the journey. I expect you'll assist us with a pair of fresh horses, as you promised. Dispatch is necessary, as the hag (ay the hag) your mother, will otherwise suspect us. Your's, Hastings. Grant me patience. I shall run distracted. My rage choaks me.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: I hope, Madam, you'll suspend your resentment for a few moments, and not impute to me any impertinence, or sinister design that belongs to another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Fine spoken, Madam, you are most miraculously polite and engaging, and quite the very pink of curtesy and circumspection, Madam. (Changing her tone.) And you, you great ill-fashioned oaf, with scarce sense enough to keep your mouth shut. Were you too join'd against me? But I'll defeat all your plots in a moment. As for you, Madam, since you have got a pair of fresh horses ready, it would be cruel to disappoint them. So, if you please, instead of running away with your spark, prepare, this very moment, to run off with me. Your old aunt Pedigree will keep you secure, I'll warrant me. You too, Sir, may mount your horse, and guard us upon the way. Here, Thomas, Roger, Diggory, I'll shew you, that I wish you better than you do yourselves.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: So now I'm completely ruined.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Ay, that's a sure thing.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: What better could be expected from being connected with such a stupid fool, and after all the nods and signs I made him.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: By the laws, Miss, it was your own cleverness, and not my stupidity, that did your business. You were so nice and so busy with your Shake-bags and Goose-greens, that I thought you could never be making believe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: So. Sir, I find by my servant, that you have shewn my letter, and betray'd us. Was this well done, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Here's another. Ask Miss there who betray'd you. Ecod, it was her doing, not mine.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: So I have been finely used here among you. Rendered contemptible, driven into ill manners, despised, insulted, laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Here's another. We shall have old Bedlam broke loose presently.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: And there, Sir, is the gentleman to whom we all owe every obligation.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: What can I say to him, a mere boy, an ideot, whose ignorance and age are a protection.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: A poor contemptible booby, that would but disgrace correction.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Yet with cunning and malice enough to make himself merry with all our embarrassments.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: An insensible cub.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Replete with tricks and mischief.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Baw! damme, but I'll fight you both one after the other,—with baskets.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: As for him, he's below resentment. But your conduct, Mr. Hastings, requires an explanation. You knew of my mistakes, yet would not undeceive me.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Tortured as I am with my own disappointments, is this a time for explanations. It is not friendly, Mr. Marlow.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Mr. Marlow, we never kept on your mistake, till it was too late to undeceive you. Be pacified.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: My mistress desires you'll get ready immediately, Madam. The horses are putting to Your hat and things are in the next room. We are to go thirty miles before morning.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Well, well; I'll come presently.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Was it well done, Sir, to assist in rendering me ridiculous. To hang me out for the scorn of all my acquaintance. Depend upon it, Sir, I shall expect an explanation.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Was it well done, Sir, if you're upon that subject, to deliver what I entrusted to yourself, to the care of another, Sir.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Mr. Hastings. Mr. Marlow. Why will you increase my distress by this groundless dispute. I implore, I intreat you—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: Your cloak, Madam. My mistress is impatient.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: I come. Pray be pacified. If I leave you thus, I shall die with apprehension.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: Your fan, muff, and gloves, Madam. The horses are waiting.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: O, Mr. Marlow! if you knew what a scene of constraint and ill-nature lies before me, I'm sure it would convert your resentment into pity.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I'm so distracted with a variety of passions, that I don't know what I do. Forgive me, Madam. George, forgive me. You know my hasty temper, and should not exasperate it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: The torture of my situation is my only excuse.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Well, my dear Hastings, if you have that esteem for me that I think, that I am sure you have, your constancy for three years will but encrease the happiness of our future connexion. If—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Miss Neville. Constance, why Constance, I say.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: I'm coming. Well, constancy. Remember, constancy is the word.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: My heart! How can I support this. To be so near happiness, and such happiness.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: You see now, young gentleman, the effects of your folly. What might be amusement to you, is here disappointment, and even distress.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Ecod, I have hit it. Its here. Your hands. Yours and yours, my poor Sulky. My boots there, ho. Meet me two hours hence at the bottom of the garden; and if you don't find Tony Lumpkin a more good-natur'd fellow than you thought for, I'll give you leave to take my best horse, and Bet Bouncer into the bargain. Come along. My boots, ho.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: YOU saw the Old Lady and Miss Neville drive off, you say.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: Yes, your honour. They went off in a post coach, and the young 'Squire went on horseback. They're thirty miles off by this time.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Then all my hopes are over.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.l: Yes, Sir. Old Sir Charles is arrived. He and the Old Gentleman of the house have been laughing at Mr. Marlow's mistake this half hour. They are coming this way.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Then I must not be seen. So now to my fruitless appointment at the bottom of the garden. This is about the time.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. The peremptory tone in which he sent forth his sublime commands.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: And the reserve with which I suppose he treated all your advances.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: And yet he might have seen something in me above a common inn-keeper, too.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Yes, Dick, but he mistook you for an uncommon innkeeper, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Well, I'm in too good spirits to think of any thing but joy. Yes, my dear friend, this union of our families will make our personal friendships hereditary; and tho' my daughter's fortune is but small—

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Why, Dick, will you talk of fortune to me. My son is possessed of more than a competence already, and can want nothing but a good and virtuous girl to share his happiness and encrease it. If they like each other, as you say they do—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: If, man. I tell you they do like each other. My daughter as good as told me so.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: But girls are apt to flatter themselves, you know.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I saw him grasp her hand in the warmest manner myself; and here he comes to put you out of your iffs, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I come, Sir, once more, to ask pardon for my strange conduct. I can scarce reflect on my insolence without confusion.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Tut, boy, a trifle. You take it too gravely. An hour or two's laughing with my daughter will set all to rights again. She'll never like you the worse for it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Sir, I shall be always proud of her approbation.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Approbation is but a cold word, Mr. Marlow; if I am not deceived, you have something more than approbation thereabouts. You take me.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Really, Sir, I have not that happiness.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Come, boy, I'm an old fellow, and know what's what, as well as you that are younger. I know what has past between you; but mum.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Sure, Sir, nothing has past between us but the most profound respect on my side, and the most distant reserve on her's. You don't think, Sir, that my impudence has been past upon all the rest of the family.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Impudence! No, I don't say that—Not quite impudence—Though girls like to be play'd with, and rumpled a little too sometimes. But she has told no tales, I assure you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I never gave her the slightest cause.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Well, well, I like modesty in its place well enough. But this is over-acting, young gentleman. You may be open. Your father and I will like you the better for it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: May I die. Sir, if I ever—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I tell you, she don't dislike you; and as I'm sure you like her—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Dear Sir—I protest, Sir—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I see no reason why you should not be joined as fast as the parson can tie you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: But hear me, Sir—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Your father approves the match, I admire it, every moment's delay will be doing mischief, so—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: But why won't you hear me? By all that's just and true, I never gave miss Hardcastle the slightest mark of my attachment, or even the most distant hint to suspect me of affection. We had but one interview, and that was formal, modest and uninteresting.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: This fellow's formal modest impudence is beyond bearing.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: And you never grasp'd her hand, or made any protestations!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: As heaven is my witness, I came down in obedience to your commands. I saw the lady without emotion, and parted without reluctance. I hope you'll exact no further proofs of my duty, nor prevent me from leaving a house in which I suffer so many mortifications.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: I'm astonish'd at the air of sincerity with which he parted.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: And I'm astonish'd at the deliberate intrepidity of his assurance.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: I dare pledge my life and honour upon his truth.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Here comes my daughter, and I would stake my happiness upon her veracity.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Kate, come hither, child. Answer us sincerely, and without reserve; has Mr. Marlow made you any professions of love and affection?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: The question is very abrupt, Sir! But since you require unreserved sincerity, I think he has.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: You see.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: And pray, madam, have you and my son had more than one interview?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, several.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: You see.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: But did he profess any attachment?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: A lasting one.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Did he talk of love?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Amazing! And all this formally?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Formally.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Now, my friend, I hope you are satisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: And how did he behave, madam?

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: As most profest admirers do. Said some civil things of my face, talked much of his want of merit, and the greatness of mine; mentioned his heart, gave a short tragedy speech, and ended with pretended rapture.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Now I'm perfectly convinced, indeed. I know his conversation among women to be modest and submissive. This forward canting ranting manner by no means describes him, and I am confident, he never sate for the picture.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then what, Sir, if I should convince you to your face of my sincerity? If you and my papa, in about half an hour, will place yourselves behind that screen, you shall hear him declare his passion to me in person.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Agreed. And if I find him what you describe, all my happiness in him must have an end.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: And if you don't find him what I describe—I fear my happiness must never have a beginning.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Back of the Garden.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: What an ideot am I, to wait here for a fellow, who probably takes a delight in mortifying me. He never intended to be punctual, and I'll wait no longer. What do I see. It is he, and perhaps with news of my Constance.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: My honest 'Squire! I now find you a man of your word. This looks like friendship.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Ay, I'm your friend, and the best friend you have in the world, if you knew but all. This riding by night, by the bye, is cursedly tiresome. It has shook me worse than the basket of a stage-coach.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: But how? Where did you leave your fellow travellers? Are they in safety? Are they housed?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l:
Five and twenty miles in two hours and a half is no such bad driving. The poor beasts have smoaked for it: Rabbet me, but I'd rather ride forty miles after a fox, than ten with such
varment.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Well, but where have you left the ladies? I die with impatience.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Left them. Why where should I leave them, but where I found them.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: This is a riddle.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Riddle me this then. What's that goes round the house, and round the house, and never touches the house?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: I'm still astray.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Why that's it, mon. I have led them astray. By jingo, there's not a pond or slough within five miles of the place but they can tell the taste of.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I understand; you took them in a round, while they supposed themselves going forward. And so you have at last brought them home again.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: You shall hear. I first took them down Feather-bed-lane, where we stuck fast in the mud. I then rattled them crack over the stones of Up-and-down Hill—I then introduc'd them to the gibbet on Heavy-tree Heath, and from that, with a circumbendibus, I fairly lodged them in the horsepond at the bottom of the garden.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: But no accident, I hope.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: No, no. Only mother is confoundedly frightened. She thinks herself forty miles off. She's sick of the journey, and the cattle can scarce crawl. So if your own horses be ready, you may whip off with cousin, and I'll be bound that no soul here can budge a foot to follow you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: My dear friend, how can I be grateful?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Ay, now its dear friend, noble 'Squire. Just now, it was all ideot, cub, and run me through the guts. Damn your way of fighting, I say. After we take a knock in this part of the country, we kiss and be friends. But if you had run me through the guts, then I should be dead, and you might go kiss the hangman.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: The rebuke is just. But I must hasten to relieve miss Neville; if you keep the old lady employed, I promise to take care of the young one.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Never fear me. Here she comes. Vanish. She's got from the pond, and draggled up to the waist like a mermaid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Oh, Tony, I'm killed. Shook. Battered to death. I shall never survive it. That last jolt that laid us against the quickset hedge has done my business.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Alack, mama, it was all your own fault. You would be for running away by night, without knowing one inch of the way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I wish we were at home again. I never met so many accidents in so short a journey. Drench'd in the mud, overturn'd in a ditch, stuck fast in a slough, jolted to a jelly, and at last to lose our way. Whereabouts do you think we are, Tony?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: By my guess we should be upon Crackskull common, about forty miles from home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: O lud! O lud! the most notorious spot in all the country. We only want a robbery to make a complete night on't.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Don't be afraid, mama, don't be afraid. Two of the five that kept here are hanged, and the other three may not find us. Don't be afraid. Is that a man that's galloping behind us? No; its only a tree. Don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: The fright will certainly kill me.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Do you see any thing like a black hat moving behind the thicket?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: O death!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: No, it's only a cow. Don't be afraid, mama; don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: As I'm alive, Tony, I see a man coming towards us. Ah! I'm sure on't. If he perceives us we are undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Father-in-law, by all that's unlucky, come to take one of his night walks. [To her.] Ah, it's a highwayman, with pistils as long as my arm. A damn'd ill-looking fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Good heaven defend us! He approaches.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l:
Do you hide yourself in that thicket, and leave me to manage him. If there be any danger I'll
cough and cry hem. When I cough be sure to keep close.

div.stage: [Mrs. Hardcastle hides behind a tree in the back scene.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I'm mistaken, or I heard voices of people in want of help. Oh, Tony, is that you. I did not expect you so soon back. Are your mother and her charge in safety?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Very safe, Sir, at my aunt Pedigree's. Hem.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ah death! I find there's danger.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Forty miles in three hours; sure, that's too much, my youngster.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Stout horses and willing minds make short journies, as they say. Hem.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Sure he'll do the dear boy no harm.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: But I heard a voice here; I should be glad to know from whence it came?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: It was I, Sir, talking to myself, Sir. I was saying that forty miles in four hours was very good going. Hem. As to be sure it was. Hem. I have got a sort of cold by being out in the air. We'll go in, if you please. Hem.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: But if you talk'd to yourself, you did not answer yourself. I am certain I heard two voices, and am resolved (raising his voice) to find the other out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Oh! he's coming to find me out. Oh!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: What need you go, Sir, if I tell you. Hem. I'll lay down my life for the truth—hem—I'll tell you all, Sir.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I tell you, I will not be detained. I insist on seeing. It's in vain to expect I'll believe you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: O lud, he'll murder my poor boy, my darling. Here, good gentleman, whet your rage upon me. Take my money, my life, but spare that young gentleman, spare my child, if you have any mercy.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: My wife! as I'm a Christian. From whence can she come, or what does she mean!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Take compassion on us, good Mr. Highwayman. Take our money, our watches, all we have, but spare our lives. We will never bring you to justice, indeed we won't, good Mr. Highwayman.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I believe the woman's out of her senses. What, Dorothy, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Mr. Hardcastle, as I'm alive! My fears blinded me. But who, my dear, could have expected to meet you here, in this frightful place, so far from home. What has brought you to follow us?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l:
Sure, Dorothy, you have not lost your wits. So far from home, when you are within forty
yards of your own door. (To him.) This is one of your old tricks, you graceless rogue you. (To her.) Don't you know the gate, and the mulberry-tree; and don't you remember the horsepond, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l:
Yes, I shall remember the horsepond as long as I live; I have caught my death in it.
(To Tony.)
And is it to you, you graceless varlet, I owe all this. I'll teach you to abuse your mother, I will.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Ecod, mother, all the parish says you have spoil'd me, and so you may take the fruits on't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I'll spoil you, I will.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: There's morality, however, in his reply.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: My dear Constance, why will you deliberate thus? If we delay a moment, all is lost for ever. Pluck up a little resolution, and we shall soon be out of the reach of her malignity.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: I find it impossible. My spirits are so sunk with the agitations I have suffered, that I am unable to face any new danger. Two or three years patience will at last crown us with happiness.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Such a tedious delay is worse than inconstancy. Let us fly, my charmer. Let us date our happiness from this very moment. Perish fortune. Love and content will encrease what we possess beyond a monarch's revenue. Let me prevail.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: No, Mr. Hastings; no. Prudence once more comes to my relief, and I will obey its dictates. In the moment of passion, fortune may be despised, but it ever produces a lasting repentance. I'm resolved to apply to Mr. Hardcastle's compassion and justice for redress.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: But tho' he had the will, he has not the power to relieve you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: But he has influence, and upon that I am resolved to rely.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: I have no hopes. But since you persist, I must reluctantly obey you.

div.stage: Enter Sir CHARLES and Miss HARDCASTLE.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: What a situation am I in. If what you say appears, I shall then find a guilty son. If what he says be true, I shall then lose one that, of all others, I most wish'd for a daughter.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I am proud of your approbation, and to shew I merit it, if you place yourselves as I directed, you shall hear his explicit declaration. But he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: I'll to your father, and keep him to the appointment.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Tho' prepar'd for setting out, I come once more to take leave, nor did I, till this moment, know the pain I feel in the separation.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I believe these sufferings cannot be very great, Sir, which you can so easily remove. A day or two longer, perhaps, might lessen your uneasiness, by shewing the little value of what you now think proper to regret.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: This girl every moment improves upon me. (To her.) It must not be, Madam. I have already trifled too long with my heart. My very pride begins to submit to my passion. The disparity of education and fortune, the anger of a parent, and the contempt of my equals, begin to lose their weight; and nothing can restore me to myself, but this painful effort of resolution.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then go, Sir. I'll urge nothing more to detain you. Tho' my family be as good as her's you came down to visit, and my education, I hope, not inferior, what are these advantages without equal affluence? I must remain contented with the slight approbation of imputed merit; I must have only the mockery of your addresses, while all your serious aims are fix'd on fortune.

div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE and Sir CHARLES from behind.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Here, behind this screen.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, make no noise. I'll engage my Kate covers him with confusion at last.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: By heavens, Madam, fortune was ever my smallest consideration. Your beauty at first caught my eye; for who could see that without emotion. But every moment that I converse with you, steals in some new grace, heightens the picture, and gives it stronger expression. What at first seem'd rustic plainness, now appears refin'd simplicity. What seem'd forward assurance, now strikes me as the result of courageous innocence, and conscious virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: What can it mean! He amazes me!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: I told you how it would be. Hush!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: I am now determined to stay, Madam, and I have too good an opinion of my father's discernment, when he sees you, to doubt his approbation.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: No, Mr. Marlow, I will not, cannot detain you. Do you think I could suffer a connexion, in which there is the smallest room for repentance? Do you think I would take the mean advantage of a transient passion, to load you with confusion? Do you think I could ever relish that happiness, which was acquired by lessening your's?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l:
By all that's good, I can have no happiness but what's in your power to grant me. Nor shall I ever feel repentance, but in not having seen your merits before. I will stay, even contrary to your wishes; and tho' you should persist to shun me, I
will make my respectful assiduities atone for the levity of my past conduct.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Sir, I must entreat you'll desist. As our acquaintance began, so let it end, in indifference. I might have given an hour or two to levity; but feriously, Mr. Marlow, do you think I could ever submit to a connexion, where I must appear mercenary, and you imprudent? Do you think I could ever catch at the confident addresses of a secure admirer?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Does this look like security. Does this look like confidence. No, Madam, every moment that shews me your merit only serves to encrease my diffidence and confusion. Here let me continue—

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: I can hold it no longer. Charles, Charles, how hast thou deceived me! Is this your indifference, your uninteresting conversation!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Your cold contempt; your formal interview. What have you to say now?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: That I'm all amazement! What can it mean!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: It means that you can say and unsay things at pleasure. That you can address a lady in private, and deny it in public; that you have one story for us, and another for my daughter.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Daughter!—this lady your daughter!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, my only daughter. My Kate, whose else should she be.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Oh, the devil.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, that very identical tall squinting lady you were pleased to take me for, (curtesying.) She that you addressed as the mild, modest, sentimental man of gravity, and the bold forward agreeable rattle of the ladies club; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Zounds, there's no bearing this; it's worse than death.

sp.speaker: Miss HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: In which of your characters, Sir, will you give us leave to address you. As the faultering gentleman, with looks on the ground, that speaks just to be heard, and hates hypocrisy; or the loud confident creature, that keeps it up with Mrs. Mantrap, and old Miss Biddy Buckskin, till three in the morning; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: O, curse on my noisy head. I never attempted to be impudent yet, that I was not taken down. I must be gone.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: By the hand of my body, but you shall not. I see it was all a mistake, and I am rejoiced to find it. You shall not, Sir, I tell you. I know she'll forgive you. Won't you forgive him, Kate. We'll all forgive you. Take courage, man.

div.stage: [They retire, she tormenting him to the back Scene.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: So, so, they're gone off. Let them go, I care not.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Who gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: My dutiful niece and her gentleman, Mr. Hastings, from Town. He who came down with our modest visitor here.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: Who, my honest George Hastings. As worthy a fellow as lives, and the girl could not have made a more prudent choice.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Then, by the hand of my body, I'm proud of the connexion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Well, if he has taken away the lady, he has not taken her fortune, that remains in this family to console us for her loss.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Sure Dorothy you would not be so mercenary?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ay, that's my affair, not your's. But you know if your son, when of age, refuses to marry his cousin, her whole fortune is then at her own disposal.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Ay, but he's not of age, and she has not thought proper to wait for his refusal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: What returned so soon, I begin not to like it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l:
For my late attempt to fly off with your niece, let my present confusion be
my punishment. We are now come back, to appeal from your justice to your humanity. By her father's consent, I first paid her my addresses, and our passions were first founded in duty.

sp.speaker: Miss NEVILLE.
sp.l: Since his death, I have been obliged to stoop to dissimulation to avoid oppression. In an hour of levity, I was ready even to give up my fortune to secure my choice. But I'm now recover'd from the delusion, and hope from your tenderness what is denied me from a nearer connexion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Pshaw, pshaw, this is all but the whining end of a modern novel.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Be it what it will, I'm glad they're come back to reclaim their due. Come hither, Tony boy. Do you refuse this lady's hand whom I now offer you?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: What signifies my refusing. You know I can't refuse her till I'm of age, father.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: While I thought concealing your age boy was likely to conduce to your improvement, I concurred with your mother's desire to keep it secret. But since I find she turns it to a wrong use, I must now declare, you have been of age these three months.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l: Of age! Am I of age, father?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: Above three months.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.l:
Then you'll see the first use I'll make of my liberty. (taking miss Neville's hand.) Witness all men by these presents, that I, Anthony Lumpkin,
Esquire, of BLANK place, refuse you, Constantia Neville, spinster, of no place at all, for my true and lawful wife. So Constance Neville may marry whom she pleases, and Tony Lumpkin is his own man again.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.l: O brave 'Squire.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: My worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: My undutiful offspring.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.l: Joy, my dear George, I give you joy sincerely. And could I prevail upon my little tyrant here to be less arbitrary, I should be the happiest man alive, if you would return me the favour.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.l: Come, madam, you are now driven to the very last scene of all your contrivances. I know you like him, I'm sure he loves you, and you must and shall have him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.l: And I say so too. And Mr. Marlow, if she makes as good a wife as she has a daughter, I don't believe you'll ever repent your bargain. So now to supper, to-morrow we shall gather all the poor of the parish about us, and the Mistakes of the Night shall be crowned with a merry morning; so boy take her; and as you have been mistakenn in the mistress, my wish is, that you may never be mistaken in the wife.

div.head:
EPILOGUE
To be Spoken in the Character of TONY LUMPKIN.

lg.l: WELL— now all's ended—and my comrades gone,
Pray what becomes of mother's nonly son?
A hopeful blade!—in town I'll fix my station,
And try to make a bluster in the nation.
As for my cousin Neville, I renounce her,
Off—in a crack—I'll carry big Bett Bouncer.
Why should not I in the great world appear?
I soon shall have a thousand pounds a year;
No matter what a man may here inherit,
In London—'gad, they've some regard to spirit.
I see the horses prancing up the streets,
And big Bet Bouncer, bobs to all she meets;
Then hoikes to jiggs and pastimes ev'ry night—
Not to the plays—they say it a'n't polite,
To Sadler's-Wells perhaps, or Operas go,
And once by chance, to the roratorio.
Thus here and there, for ever up and down,
We'll set the fashions too, to half the town;
And then at auctions—money ne'er regard,
Buy pictures like the great, ten pounds a yard;
Zounds, we shall make these London gentry say,
We know what's damn'd genteel, as well as they. * This came too late to be Spoken.[Goldsmith's note]
